tweet_text: If Phineas and Ferb were involved, the vaccine would have been created already.
As a vaccine checker at a venue tonight, I couldn't believe it when a couple straight-up asked me, "Vaccine for what?" I'm not joking – I was completely baffled by their question.

The nurse administering my vaccine gave approval for me to use a bandaid I brought from home, saying "I don't see any issue with that". However, she may have changed her opinion since then, as indicated by the following HTTPURL.

In 1955, when the polio vaccine was released, people eagerly queued up to receive it. At that time, we were only two years away from launching artificial satellites. Fast forward to 2021, we carry powerful devices in our pockets that connect us to the world, and robots are exploring the surface of Mars. Despite these advancements, some individuals believe unfounded claims that the COVID-19 vaccine is dangerous.
When I inquired about any possible side effects of her second vaccine shot, my mother's response was a newfound admiration for science.

During my ballet class today, a 6-year-old student asked me if I was looking forward to receiving the COVID-19 vaccine. She referred to it as the "Fauci Ouchie" and I found her nickname for the vaccine to be absolutely adorable. From now on, I will use the same term when talking about the COVID-19 vaccine.
Despite being a nurse, Lindsey Graham received a vaccine before I did.
Utilizing their expertise in crafting a shampoo and conditioner dual-purpose product, Johnson & Johnson developed their vaccine.

My 10-year-old received the Pfizer vaccine tonight, and though he was anxious, he kept repeating his best friend's name (who is high risk). I have absolutely no remorse that my child felt frightened but still chose to act with compassion for someone else.
Dolly Parton didn't rise and shuffle to the kitchen to brew herself a cup of determination solely to have you turn down the Covid vaccine, which she financially supported.
Unfortunately, the pharmacy is out of everything except COVID vaccines, and that's not helpful because my horse has worms.

Yesterday, my aunt passed away from COVID-19 after a brief illness. Despite being fully vaccinated, she succumbed to the virus. She was on the verge of retirement, having worked as a lawyer throughout her career. She was a fierce advocate for women's rights and an active volunteer with the House of Ruth, helping victims of domestic violence. Her passing is a great loss for us all, and we mourn the departure of this beautiful soul. May she rest in peace. ️

There are several myths circulating about COVID-19, and I would like to correct one of them. The claim that the virus will disappear during the summer months is incorrect. Unlike some previous pandemics, COVID-19 is not expected to follow weather patterns. Additionally, as the Northern Hemisphere enters summer, the Southern Hemisphere will be entering winter, which means that the virus will continue to circulate globally.

The inspiring story of a 66-year-old immigrant researcher, who faced numerous challenges throughout her career, is making headlines. Despite rarely receiving grants, never having her own laboratory, and never earning more than $60K, she persisted for four decades, focused solely on mRNA, a path that many considered foolish.

Her unwavering dedication to her work has paid off, as her groundbreaking research now serves as the basis for the highly effective Pfizer and Moderna vaccines. This remarkable scientist's persistence and commitment to her studies serve as an inspiration to anyone who dreams of making a meaningful contribution to society.
